isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE / 2000 4000 and 8000 MODELS BUILT OCTOBER 1, 1998 AND AFTER - SPEEDOMETER/TACHOMETER, GAUGES AND WARNING LIGHTS - 9800 - Troubleshooting - GAUGES

svcprocinfo.para: All electronic gauges are of the electromagnetic air core type. In each system to be monitored (Fuel Level, Oil Temperature, Water Temperature, etc.) a sender uses a variable resistance to control current from the battery through a coil or coils in the gauge.

svcsubproc.title: Gauge Tester
svcsubproc.para: To assist in checking the electrical indicating type gauges, use of a universal-type Gauge Tester ZTSE-2781 (Figure 16) is suggested. This test eliminates time consuming trial and error methods of checking out the gauges.

To test gauge operation, the sender wire is disconnected from the sender unit and the tester is connected between the sender wire and ground. The tester substitutes for the sender unit, as shown in (Figure 17).
Procedures and resistance settings for the gauge tester are given in the troubleshooting table for each gauge.

svcsubproc.title: Gauge Quick Checks
svcsubproc.para: If a universal gauge tester is not available, electrical gauges can also be "quick-checked" to determine if they are functioning by a simple "Sender Disconnect and Ground Test". This test tells only that the gauge is functioning. It does not determine if gauge is accurate. Procedures for the quick test are given in the "quick test" troubleshooting table for each gauge.
